title: Three line no-serif typeface
content:
Hi again!  
It seems that my participation on this forum is about Type ID, well maybe in some time i get the knowledge to make other kind of statements.

Well, i'm looking for this font (or a similar one) to use on a work. Can anyone help?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Imagem 1.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118043054/http:/typophile.com/files/Imagem%201.png) | 146.26 KB |
author: sendoushi

comments.content: Most of the letters by outline look to be a dead ringer for Avenir 85 Heavy. The K, H and S are throwing me. Possibly all modified? I'll keep my eyes peeled...
Actually, even closer to Neuziet S BookHeavy. Same problem with the K and H but almost all the other characters are a perfect match.

I see... i'll try, if you find anything like that please... say it... and thanks.

Joel Santos // youremin  
sound & visual
Also check out Mike’s fabulous [Lined Font Identification Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20130118043054/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/LinedFontGuide01.html).

Florian, because I really really needed to procrastinate, I looked through the whole guide - I didn't see any fonts that were close. The "T" with the three bands across the top and then three bands down, with no "T" intersection, seems to be unusual.

---  
eeblet.com

I agree that it's not in my Guide, and I checked the several Dover books I have with type like this and didn't see a match. That included the Solotype Catalog. It resembles Neon that someone re-drew as a Prisma-style font. I thought someone once described a way to fake this look in Illustrator with some sort of outline/offset technique, but I have no other ideas, other than check freebies at Dafont.

- Mike Yanega
